title: Antoine Deparcieux
text:
Antoine Deparcieux (28 October 17032 September 1768) was a <a href="French%20people">French</a> <a href="mathematician">mathematician</a>.
He was born at <a href="Clessous">Clessous</a> in the <a href="Portes%2C%20Gard">Portes</a>, department of <a href="Gard">Gard</a>. He attended the school of <a href="Saint-Florent-sur-Auzonnet">Saint Florent</a> for 10 years while working on his family farm. In 1725, his desire for learning took him to <a href="Lyon">Lyon</a>, where he studied at a <a href="Society%20of%20Jesus">Jesuit</a> school for five years. Then, in 1730, he went to <a href="Paris">Paris</a> to increase his knowledge of <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a> and <a href="physics">physics</a>. He made a living by manufacturing <a href="sundial">sundial</a>s.
In 1746, he became a member of the <a href="Acad%C3%A9mie%20des%20Sciences">Academy of Sciences</a>, and in about 1765 was named "Censeur Royal". He was also librarian at the <a href="University%20of%20Strasbourg">University of Strasbourg</a>, and member of the Academy of Sciences of Paris, Montpellier, Lyon, Amiens, Metz, Berlin, and Stockholm.

In 1758, Deparcieux was elected a foreign member of the <a href="Royal%20Swedish%20Academy%20of%20Sciences">Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences</a>.
